newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australian Broadcasting Corp Afternoon Update.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australian Broadcasting Corp Afternoon Update.

text.p: AIRBAGS OPERATING AT LOW SPEEDS
National insurer, the N-R-M-A, says airbags are unnecessarily activated in low speed crashes in a number of vehicles.
Tests by the N-R-M-A on 27 vehicles found airbags activated in seven cases, at speeds of 15 kilometres an hour.
Industry Research Manager, Robert McDonald, says airbags should not be activated at such low speeds.
Mr McDonald says the activation of airbags adds four-thousand dollars to the repair cost of the vehicles.
TREATY REFUSAL AN OMINOUS SIGN, SAYS YUNUPINGU
Aboriginal leader Gallarwuy Yunupingu says the federal government would sign the European Union's trade treaty if it really intended to represent all Australians.

Mr Yunupingu, the chairman of the Northern Land Council, says the government's refusal to sign a human rights clause means it must be planning to affect the rights of indigenous and ethnic Australians.
The Land Council has prepared a report for the EU detailing Australia's human rights record towards Aborigines.
Mr Yunupingu says it will look bad internationally if Australia doesn't sign the treaty.
FORMER SALVO FACES SEX CHARGES
A former Salvation Army Officer has appeared in the Perth Magistrate's Court charged with 77 sex offences.
Charles Allan Smith was extradited from Tasmania earlier this week to face the charges which date between 1958 and 1976.
The charges include indecent dealings with children under the age of 14 and gross indecency.
Mr Smith was not required to plead to the charges and he was granted 10-thousand dollars bail to appear in court again in a fortnight.
However, it's understood Mr Smith will remain in custody because he's unable to obtain a surety for his bail.
TORRENTIAL RAIN THREATENS NSW WITH MORE FLOODS
In north-west New South Wales, State Emergency Services have gone on alert following torrential rain.
A watch is being kept on the Peel River, which flows through the city of Tamworth, after falls of up to 100 millimetres in the region.
The railway line near Murrurundi has been washed out and many minor roads have already been cut.
The Weather Buearu has also issued a minor to moderate flood warning for the Namoi River at Wee Waa and warned of severe thunderstorms for parts of the region this afternoon.
WORD EXPECTED ON CENTURY ZINC FUTURE
Crucial talks are taking place in the north west Queensland city of Mount Isa, on whether the world's biggest zinc deposit, Century Zinc, should be mined.
Aboriginal groups are still talking with mining company CRA, which is offering a 60-million dollar package if the billion dollar project goes ahead.
If the midnight deadline for agreement passes without agreement the project goes to a six month process of arbitration.
That could threaten the sale of the deposit and mean the mine won't proceed.
